article_text:
Damian Myers, an associate at Proskauer, and Nicholas Bagley, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, discuss the latest republican victory in their longstanding fight against Obamacare, which came after federal judge Rosemary Collyer ruled that the House of Representatives had legal standing to sue the president over how he was enforcing the affordable care act. In a ruling on Thursday, Collyer took down a key part of the healthcare plan, which would reduce consumers’ out of pocket medical expenses, arguing that it is unconstitutional because it relied on money that had not been appropriated by congress. They speak with Bloomberg Law hosts June Grasso and Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio’s "Bloomberg Law."

producer: June Grasso/David Sucherman +1-212-617-5560 or jgrasso4@bloomberg.net

Running time 15:59

Download: Bloomberg Law: Obamacare Suffers Another Setback (Audio)

In a ruling on Thursday, Collyer took down a key part of the healthcare plan, which would reduce consumers’ out of pocket medical expenses, arguing that it is unconstitutional because it relied on money that had not been appropriated by congress.
Damian Myers, an associate at Proskauer, and Nicholas Bagley, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, discuss the latest republican victory in their longstanding fight against Obamacare, which came after federal judge Rosemary Collyer ruled that the House of Representatives had legal standing to sue the president over how he was enforcing the affordable care act.
